SEARCH
Package danogl.util

Class Vector2

java.lang.Object
danogl.util.Vector2
Direct Known Subclasses:
MutableVector2
public class Vector2 extends Object
An immutable class representing a 2D vector. May represent a position, velocity, acceleration etc. None of the methods alter the initial x or y coordinates of the created vector; some methods return a variation of this vector. CAUTION: though a reference of this type can not alter the underlying object, it does not mean the object may not change via another reference (contrary to most immutable classes), as this class can be inherited (an object of the subclass may be mutable).
Author:
Dan Nirel

    • zeroedAlongNormal

      public Vector2 zeroedAlongNormal(Vector2 normal)
      Returns the component of this vector that is perpendicular to the given normal.

    • flipped

      public Vector2 flipped(Vector2 normal)
      Returns a new vector. The component of the new vector perpendicular to the given normal is equal to this vector's. The component of the new vector parallel to the normal is the negation of this vector's. May be used to simulate semi-elastic collisions if flipping a velocity vector relative to the collision normal.

    • rotatedToNearestAxis

      public Vector2 rotatedToNearestAxis()
      Returns a new vector with an equal magnitude, but whose direction is either down, up, right, or left - depending on which is the closest.

    • rotated

      public Vector2 rotated(float degreesCounterclockwise)
      Returns a new vector which is the rotation of this one by the given angle.
      Parameters:
      degreesCounterclockwise - The angle by which to rotate counter-clockwise, in degrees

      public int hashCode()
      Overrides:
      hashCode in class Object

    • getImmutableCopy

      public Vector2 getImmutableCopy()
      This method should be called if the user requires a copy of the coordinates that would not be altered outside their control. If this vector is already immutable, this incurs no overhead and simply returns the object itself. Calling the method is still necessary for cases where the underlying vector is an instance of a mutable subclass.

    • createVec

      protected Vector2 createVec(float x, float y)
